name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus, to Clusius, Carolus, 1598-02-22

Diplomatic.text:
<body>Carolo Clusio S[alutem] D[ico].
 Pergrata mihi <ab id="9027055"/>epistola<ae id="9027055"/> quae de meliore valetudine tua nuntiabat, mi Clusi. O longum ita sit et in hac aetate <ab id="9027056"/>vel serpentis instar<ae id="9027056"/> (si vera est fides) iuvenesce. <ab id="9027058"/>Me haec hiems<ae id="9027058"/> et mea <ab id="9027059"/>bilis<ae id="9027059"/> semper tunc acrior adfatim exercuerunt. Tamen adsurgo et vires ac spiritus recipio pauxillatim. Magis utrumque, si beata illa Pax adveniat, quae e nubibus caput paullum exserit et se ostentat. Si monstra non impediunt, fruemur; et ego te fortasse ac veteribus amicis quos loca ea habent. O Deus, <ab id="9027061"/>da pondus huic voto<ae id="9027061"/>! Quod quaeris de <ab id="9027060"/>Giselini<ae id="9027060"/> mei natali aut <ab id="9027062"/>mortuali<ae id="9027062"/> die, scito certum me non scire. Neque hic copia est quaerendi. Novi ab annis triginta virum et credo fuisse quinquennio aut sexennio me maiorem. Obiit autem, ut mea memoria est, ante <ab id="9027063"/>annos circiter septem, id est circa quinquagesimum aetatis<ae id="9027063"/>. Hactenus possum dicere et te, mi Clusi, opto <ab id="9027064"/>valide valere<ae id="9027064"/>. Lovanii, VIII. Kal[endas] Mart[ias] M.D.XCVIII.</body>

annotations.text: mortuali: A very rare variant of mortalis. Classical only as mortualia in Cat. frg. 19, Plaut. Asin. 808 and Gell. 18, 7 and mortualibus in Naev. trag. 43.
valide valere: Lipsius could have been thinking of Plaut. Pers. 427 or Truc. 126.
epistola: Not preserved. There is a gap of nearly two years in the preserved correspondence.
Giselini: Victor Giselinus (Zandvoorde 22 March 1539 - Sint-Winoksbergen 1591), a friend of Dousa, whom he introduced to Lipsius.On his death, cf. ILE V, 92 10 09.

type.description: Name of person, if possible with PE-number in BIA
type.name: Person

annotations.text: annos ... aetatis: Lipsius’s calculations are about right. Giselinus was eight years his senior (° 1539), not five or six. The date of his death is correct (1591). This makes Giselinus 52 years of age when he died, not 50. Lipsius’s statement that he knew Giselinus when he was in his thirties is true, as they met in September 1570.
Me haec hiems] As usual, Lipsius was complaining of infections of the respiratory way during the wintermonths.
bilis: In the autumn of 1584 Lipsius suffered an infection of the liver and his health remained delicate ever after.
